3.text: This report details exploration carried out on the Porphyry East tenement P31/1625 during the

4.text: reporting period 19/02/2005 to 18/02/2006. Jackson Gold is the beneficial and/or registered

5.text: holder of the tenement. The Porphyry East Project is located approximately 140 km northeast

6.text: of Kalgoorlie (Figure 1). The Project area lies between Lake Rebecca to the south and Lake

7.text: Raeside  to  the  north  and  is  located  5  km  to  the  northeast  of  the  Porphyry  Gold  Mine.  The

8.text: tenement is located on the Edjudina 1:250 000 Sheet (H 51-06) and is situated in the Yerilla

9.text: District of the North Coolgardie Mineral Field.

11.text: Tenement  P31/1625  is  underlain  by  linear  north-northwest  trending  mafic  volcanics  with

12.text: minor interflow sediments of the Morelands Formation. The Moreland Formation is part of the

13.text: Murrin  -  Margaret  Sector  which  is  bounded  to  the  west  by  the  Keith  –  Kilkenny  Tectonic

14.text: Zone and to the east by the Laverton Tectonic Zone.

 The Porphyry East Project is located approximately 140 km northeast of Kalgoorlie (Figure 1). 
 The Project area lies between Lake Rebecca to the south and Lake Raeside to the north and is 
 located  5  km  to  the  northeast  of  the  Porphyry  Gold  Mine.  The  tenement  is  located  on  the

13.text: Access to the project area is via the Kalgoorlie - Pinjin – Edjudina road. Topography consists

14.text: of low rolling hills dissected by north easterly trending creeks. The elevation varies between

15.text: 400m  and  420m.    The  physiography  is  to  a  large  extent  related  to  the  underlying  geology.

16.text: Northwest  –striking  ridges  are  underlain  by  mafic rocks and banded iron-formations. Areas

17.text: underlain  by  greenstones  and  granitoids  are  gently  undulating  with  plateaus  of  laterite  and

53.text: Gold mineralisation is present in several linear north-northwest trending zones of alteration in

54.text: a variety of host rocks in the vicinity of tenement P31/1625. These mineralised trends include

55.text: the  Edjudina  line  –  hosted  in  sediments  and  acid  volcanics;  the  Yarri  –  Great  Banjo  line  –

56.text: hosted in granites and mafic volcanics; the Margaret – Penola and Dead Dog lines – hosted in

57.text: intermediate volcanics; and the Porphyry trend – hosted in a quartz monzonite stock.

text:
Gold mineralisation is present in several linear north-northwest trending zones of alteration in 
 a variety of host rocks in the vicinity of tenement P31/1625. These mineralised trends include 
 the  Edjudina  line  –  hosted  in  sediments  and  acid  volcanics;  the  Yarri  –  Great  Banjo  line  – 
 hosted in granites and mafic volcanics; the Margaret – Penola and Dead Dog lines – hosted in 
 intermediate volcanics; and the Porphyry trend – hosted in a quartz monzonite stock.

36.text: The Porphyry East Project areas lie within the eastern part of the Eastern Goldfields Province

37.text: of the Yilgarn Craton (Swager, 1995). The project occurs along the eastern boundary of the

38.text: Norseman-  Wiluna  Belt.    The  tenement  lies  within  the  Mulgabbie  domain  of  the  Kurnalpi

39.text: terrane.  In  this  terrane,  greenstone  units  form  a  west-dipping  homoclinal  sequence  that  has

42.text: metamorphosed  mafic  volcanics  and  intrusives,  predominantly  amphibolite  and  metabasalt,

43.text: minor ultramafics and biotite monzogranite plutons (Figure 3.).

45.text: Tenement P31/1625 is underlain by linear north-northwest trending mafic volcanics with

46.text: minor interflow sediments of the Morelands Formation. The Moreland Formation is part of the

47.text: Murrin - Margaret Sector which is bounded to the west by the Keith – Kilkenny Tectonic

48.text: Zone and to the east by the Laverton Tectonic Zone. Major north-northwest trending strike

49.text: faults, including the Kilkenny and Mount Celia faults have been recognised in the area.

 The Porphyry East Project areas lie within the eastern part of the Eastern Goldfields Province 
 of the Yilgarn Craton (Swager, 1995). The project occurs along the eastern boundary of the 
 Norseman-  Wiluna  Belt.    The  tenement  lies  within  the  Mulgabbie  domain  of  the  Kurnalpi 
 terrane.  In  this  terrane,  greenstone  units  form  a  west-dipping  homoclinal  sequence  that  has 
 metamorphosed  mafic  volcanics  and  intrusives,  predominantly  amphibolite  and  metabasalt, 
 faults.  The  Mulgabbie  domain  comprises 
 late,  north-trending 
 minor ultramafics and biotite monzogranite plutons (Figure 3.).  
 Tenement P31/1625 is underlain by linear north-northwest trending mafic volcanics with 
 minor interflow sediments of the Morelands Formation. The Moreland Formation is part of the 
 Murrin - Margaret Sector which is bounded to the west by the Keith – Kilkenny Tectonic 
 Zone and to the east by the Laverton Tectonic Zone. Major north-northwest trending strike 
 faults, including the Kilkenny and Mount Celia faults have been recognised in the area.

4.text: The main line of workings within the Yarri Monzogranite, almost 1500 m long, encompasses

5.text: the  more  or  less  contiguous  workings  at  Wallaby  North,  Wallaby  Central,  and  Yarri

6.text: Proprietary. The workings have exposed a 330 – 340o –trending, subvertical to steeply west

7.text: dipping  shear  zone  that  is  more  or  less  conformable  within  the  regional  foliation.  The

8.text: mineralized shears are commonly located at the margins of prominent quartz veins of similar

9.text: orientation. They represent zones of relatively high strain that may have been localized by the

10.text: contrast in competency between the veins and the wall rocks. Farther south, the mafic-hosted

11.text: workings at Star of Yarri (Beatrice) and Queens Birthday, appear to lie on a different trend to

12.text: that defined by the monzogranite-hosted deposits. The structure at Yarri South is a steeply east

13.text: dipping, banded brittle-ductile shear zone (Roberts, F.I. et al., 2000).

15.text: The Porphyry and Million Dollar deposits occur within two 20o - 25o east-dipping shear zones

16.text: within  the  Porphyry  Quartz  Monzonite.  The  Porphyry  shear  zone,  which  cuts  the  eastern

17.text: margin  of  the  intrusion,  is  approximately  25m  wide.  Gold  is  localized  in  a  series  of  en

18.text: echeolon lenses, with the highest grades contained within mylonitic zones about 10cm thick

19.text: (Swager, 1995). The alteration mineralogy is quartz-muscovite-pyrite, and probably includes

20.text: fine-grained hematite produced at a late stage of mineralisation. The low-grade Million Dollar

21.text: mineralized shear occurs some 350 m above the Porphyry shear and two kilometres south of

text:
produced 40 kg of gold (Roberts, F.I. et al., 2000).  
 The main line of workings within the Yarri Monzogranite, almost 1500 m long, encompasses 
 the  more  or  less  contiguous  workings  at  Wallaby  North,  Wallaby  Central,  and  Yarri 
 Proprietary. The workings have exposed a 330 – 340o –trending, subvertical to steeply west 
 dipping  shear  zone  that  is  more  or  less  conformable  within  the  regional  foliation.  The 
 mineralized shears are commonly located at the margins of prominent quartz veins of similar 
 orientation. They represent zones of relatively high strain that may have been localized by the 
 contrast in competency between the veins and the wall rocks. Farther south, the mafic-hosted 
 workings at Star of Yarri (Beatrice) and Queens Birthday, appear to lie on a different trend to 
 that defined by the monzogranite-hosted deposits. The structure at Yarri South is a steeply east 
 dipping, banded brittle-ductile shear zone (Roberts, F.I. et al., 2000).  
 The Porphyry and Million Dollar deposits occur within two 20o - 25o east-dipping shear zones 
 within  the  Porphyry  Quartz  Monzonite.  The  Porphyry  shear  zone,  which  cuts  the  eastern 
 margin  of  the  intrusion,  is  approximately  25m  wide.  Gold  is  localized  in  a  series  of  en 
 echeolon lenses, with the highest grades contained within mylonitic zones about 10cm thick 
 (Swager, 1995). The alteration mineralogy is quartz-muscovite-pyrite, and probably includes 
 fine-grained hematite produced at a late stage of mineralisation. The low-grade Million Dollar 
 mineralized shear occurs some 350 m above the Porphyry shear and two kilometres south of 
 The eastern margin of tenement P31/1625 is covered by sand derived from the adjacent granite 
 terrane. The western portion appears from the Landsat TM image to be of a residual nature 
 It is evident from the regional aeromagnetic data that the majority of the structures trend in a 
 northwest  direction,  parallel  to  stratigraphy  (Figure  5.)  The  low  angle  regional  shear  zones 
 bound or truncate lithologic – stratigraphic packages.  
 The  post-regional  folding  granitoids  including  the  Porphyry  Quartz  Monzonite,  are  clearly 
 evident  in  the  aeromagnetic  data  from  their  ellipsoidal  signature.  Granitoids,  including  the 
 Yarri Monzogranite, emplaced prior to regional folding occur as sheets which are generally 
 conformable with overall greenstone layering

5.text: The Edjudina Region was first examined by prospectors at the beginning of the last centaury

6.text: and several gold deposits were located and worked at that time. Modern exploration began in

7.text: the  early  1970’s  when  the  areas  underlain  by  ultramafic  rocks  were  examined  for  nickel

8.text: mineralisation  but  with  no  success.  This  was  followed  by  exploration  for  volcanogenic

text:
4.1 Exploration History 
 The Edjudina Region was first examined by prospectors at the beginning of the last centaury 
 and several gold deposits were located and worked at that time. Modern exploration began in 
 the  early  1970’s  when  the  areas  underlain  by  ultramafic  rocks  were  examined  for  nickel 
 mineralisation  but  with  no  success.  This  was  followed  by  exploration  for  volcanogenic

text:
Statistical  levelling  of  the  gold  from  the  surface  geochemical  database  which  includes  both

 has  been  conducted  by  Jonno  King  during  the  2005  work  year.  The  geochemical  data  set 
 comprises numerous discrete surveys or batches, the presence of differing backgrounds and 
 thresholds  commonly  causes  ‘edge  effects’  that  can  obscure  real  data  trends.  Levelling
